text: Canonical NF-kappaB signalling and negative regulators .

Ligand engagement of specific membrane receptors such as <extra_id_0> TNFR1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> trigger the recruitment of specific adaptor proteins ( <extra_id_0> TNF receptor 1-associated death domain protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> MAL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TIR domain-containing adaptor-inducing IFNbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRIF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ) , kinases ( <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IRAK4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , and ubiquitin ligases ( <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> cIAP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> cIAP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) to the receptor .

K63 - linked polyubiquitination of TRAFs , <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is recognised by <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and TAB proteins , resulting in the recruitment and activation of respectively <extra_id_0> IKK2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

<extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> then phosphorylates and activates <extra_id_0> IKK2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which in turn phosphorylates <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , triggering its K48 - linked ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation .

This allows NF-kappaB ( here shown as a heterodimer of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) to translocate to the nucleus and promote target gene expression .
<extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which has no ubiquitin ligase activity , can negatively regulate NF-kappaB activation , most probably by competing with other TRAFs .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are deubiquitinating enzymes that control NF-kappaB activation by targeting specific signalling proteins including <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , to which they are recruited using specific ubiquitin - binding adaptor proteins such as <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p62 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
miR-146 is thought to negatively regulate TLR signalling by inhibiting expression of <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Finally , TLR signalling can also be inhibited by the transmembrane protein <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which has been proposed to compete with <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for binding to <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The expression of many of these negative regulatory molecules is NF-kappaB dependent , implicating them in the negative feedback regulation of NF-kappaB activation .
